note.p: William F. Dowd was a prominent Mississippi attorney who served as a Confederate officer during the Civil War.

Born at Society Hill, South Carolina, on December 31, 1820, Dowd moved as a child with his parents to Tennessee. He moved to Mississippi in 1841 and began to study law. He became a practicing attorney in 1846 and soon joined the firm of Coopwood, Herbert & Dowd in Aberdeen, Mississippi. His found tremendous success through is legal career, becoming one of the wealthiest attorneys in the state. Dowd’s income in 1854 was estimated to be $20,000—more nearly $700,000 in modern figures. His fame as an attorney and public speaker naturally led him to politics, and he became editor of a pro-Whig Party newspaper in Aberdeen in the 1850s.

Dowd strongly supported Mississippi’s right to secession, and when the Civil War broke out in 1861, he helped raise a regiment of volunteers, later accepted into Confederate service as the Twenty-fourth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He was elected colonel in command of the unit and led it through numerous battles, including Corinth, Perryville, Lookout Mountain, and Missionary Ridge. He resigned from command late in the war due to health problems and accepted an appointment as a military judge in northern Alabama.

After the Civil War, Dowd returned to practicing law in Mississippi until he passed away on November 28, 1872, in Aberdeen. He was married to Ann W. Brown and had at least three children that survived to adulthood. Dowd is buried at Odd Fellows Rest Cemetery in Aberdeen, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; Biographical and Historical Memoris of Mississippi, Vol. 1, 659)

note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

Located in Clark County, Camp Quitman was a Confederate training camp established as early as May 1862. (Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 574)
Located in Nassau County, Fernandina was founded in the 1680s and serves as the county seat. (Britannica)
Located in Lauderdale County, Marion was founded as early as 1840. (Wikipedia)

Currently located in Chatham County, Savannah was founded in 1733. On March 16, 1758 it became part of the newly created Christ Church Parish. When Chatham County was created on February 6, 1777, it became its county seat. Savannah served as the state capital of Georgia from 1751 until 1786, when it was replaced by Augusta. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Levy County, Florida, Cedar Key was founded as early as 1845. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
The Atlantic Ocean is a salt water region located east of the Americas and west of Europe and Africa. It is 32,870,000 square miles and has a maximum depth of 27,480 feet. (Wikipedia)

Located in Kings, Queens, New York, Bronx, and Richmond counties, New York was founded around 1624. In 1626 it was known as New Amsterdam and was chartered in 1653. It was renamed New York in 1664, and briefly had its name changed to New Orange from July 1673 until November 1674. New York served as the capital of the United States from 1785 until 1790. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located in Orleans Parish, New Orleans was founded in 1718. It became the capital of French Louisiana in 1722 and continued as the capital when Louisiana achieved statehood on April 30, 1812. It became part of Orleans County (now extinct) on the same day. In 1849 it was replaced by Baton Rouge as the state capital, although it temporarily served as the capital again from 1865 until 1880. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Mobile County, Mobile was founded in 1702 and serves as the county seat. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia)

Located in Harrison County, Ship Island was founded in 1699 under the name Surgeres and renamed Ship Island in 1702. Ship Island is a barrier island in the Gulf of Mexico. (Wikipedia; Rowland, Mississippi, 662)

The act of beginning to fight or a period of time in a war, military engagements are also referred to as battles or skirmishes. Battles are fights between armed forces, and usually describe singular events that occur over the course of hours or a few days. Skirmishes are smaller fights, usually between a small number of soldiers that occur unexpectedly, last only a few minutes or a few hours, and take place away from the main area of fighting.

There were approximately 10,500 engagements during the American Civil War. Fifty of them were major battles, while another one hundred were notable engagements. The rest were small battles or skirmishes. (Cambridge Dictionary; American Battlefield Trust)

catDesc.term: Military Engagements--Ball's Bluff, Battle of, Va., 1861

gloss.p: The Battle of Ball’s Bluff (also known as the Battle of Leesburg) was fought on October 21, 1861 near the town of Leesburg, Loudoun County, Virginia between Union forces under the command of Brig. Gen. Charles P. Stone and Confederate forces under the command of Col. Nathan G. Evans. It resulted in a Confederate victory. The battle was the result of false intelligence. On the evening of October 20 a Union scouting party crossed the Potomac River to locate Confederate positions near Leesburg, and in the dim light of dusk, mistook a line of trees for the tents of an undefended Confederate encampment. Based on this faulty intelligence, Stone sent Col. Charles Devens with 300 men across the Potomac River at first light. Instead of finding a camp, Devens encountered a company of Mississippi infantry. Both sides sent reinforcements to their positions and by the afternoon, the Union forces had become encircled. The Confederates drove the Union forces off the bluff and into the Potomac River where many drowned attempting to escape. Hundreds more were taken prisoner. The total number of forces engaged in the battle were 3,429; 1,720 Union and 1,709 Confederate. Casualties were estimated at 1,157 with 1,002 Union and 155 Confederate. The Union’s significant defeat in the battle resulted in Congress creating the Joint Committee on the Conduct of the War to oversee the administration of the Army and Navy. Also of note, Col. Edward Dickinson Baker, a Senator from Oregon became the only sitting member of the U.S. Congress to die in battle. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Military Engagements--Bull Run, 1st Battle of, Va., 1861

gloss.p: The First Battle of Bull Run (also known as the First Battle of Manassas, Battle of First Manassas, and Manassas Junction) was fought on July 21, 1861 near the village of Manassas (formerly in Prince William County), Virginia between the Union Army of Northeastern Virginia (predecessor to the Union Army of the Potomac) under the command of Brig. Gen. Irvin McDowell and the Confederate Army of the Potomac (predecessor to the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia) under the command of Gen. P.G.T. Beauregard. It was the first major battle of the Civil War and resulted in a Confederate Victory. McDowell was sent south from Washington D.C. with orders to capture the Confederate Capital at Richmond, Virginia and was halted at Bull Run Creek by Beauregard’s army. A combination of poor intelligence and inexperience led to a disastrous Union defeat. McDowell was relieved of duty after the battle and replaced by Maj. Gen. George B. McClellan. The total number of forces engaged in the battle was 60,680; 28,450 Union, 32,230 Confederate. Casualties from the battle were estimated at 4,878 with 2,896 Union and 1,982 Confederate. The battle is significant because it made clear to the United States and Confederate governments that the war would not be quickly won by either side. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia)

The Battle of Somerset (also known as the Battle of Dutton’s Hill) was fought on March 31, 1863 near Somerset, Pulaski County, Kentucky between Union forces commanded by Brig. Gen. Quincy Adams Gillmore and Confederate forces commanded by Brig. Gen. John Pegram and resulted in a Union victory. Pegram led a large cavalry raid into Union-controlled Kentucky in late March 1863. He captured Danville and the surrounding vicinity, taking several hundred heads of cattle, but was pursued by Gilmore’s cavalry force. On March 29, Pegram took up a defensive position on Dutton’s Hill near Somerset. Gillmore attacked this position on March 30. That evening, Pegram retreated over the Cumberland River into Tennessee. The total number of forces engaged in the battle was 2,800; 1,250 Union and 1,550 Confederate. Casualties from the battle were estimated at 230 with 30 Union and 200 Confederate. (Official Records, The War of the Rebellion, Ser. 1, Vol. 23, 11-12; Kentucky Historical Society)

Military discharges are formal notices issued to members of the armed forces confirming that they are formally released from their obligation to serve. During the American Civil War, soldiers and officers were honorably discharged from service for a variety of reasons, including severe injuries or diseases, resignation, or their unit mustering out, among other reasons. Those who were honorably discharged were eligible to reenlist or receive veterans' benefits after the war. (Wikipedia)

The end of the Civil War, which began with the surrender of Confederate forces at Appomattox Court House in April 1865, led to the largest number of military discharges. Once captured, Confederate forces became prisoners of war and parole did not formally discharge them from Confederate armies. As Union and Confederate troops demobilized, authorities moved to formally discharge troops. On June 6, 1865, U.S. President Andrew Johnson ordered the discharge of most remaining Confederate prisoners of war, a process that took two months to complete. For the significant number of soldiers who returned home without going through formal discharge processes, they had difficulty proving they had been honorably discharged from the military, which was a core requirement for many veterans' benefits and membership in veterans' associations. (Caroline E. Janney, Ends of War, p. 217)

gloss.p: The Confederate Army was the military land force of the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Known also as the Confederate States Army or Southern Army, it was established by the Provisional Confederate Congress in February 1861 and fell under the authority of Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Modeled after the U.S. Army of the 19th century, the Confederate Army technically fell into two categories: a small regular army of professional officers and soldiers (the Army of the Confederate States of America) and a much larger, temporary force of citizen soldiers intended to exist only for the duration of the war (the Provisional Army of the Confederate States). In reality, the Confederacy’s regular army never fully developed and the overwhelming majority of Confederate soldiers served in the provisional force. The distinction between the two played little role during military operations and all were generally considered to be part of the overall Confederate Army.

As many as 1,000,000 soldiers served in the Confederate Army between 1861 and 1865, although not all at one time. Most were volunteers, however, the Confederate government instituted a conscription (or draft) in April 1862—the first in U.S. or Confederate history—to increase the size of the Confederacy’s military force and encourage voluntary enlistment. The government passed two more conscription acts over the next two years. More than ten percent of the men who served in Confederate ranks were drafted.

Over ninety percent of soldiers in the Confederate Army were native-born white men. Nine percent were foreign-born white men. Several Native American units—particularly from the Cherokee, Creek, and Choctaw tribes—served within the Confederate military, especially in the trans-Mississippi theatre. The Confederate military heavily relied upon the forced labor of enslaved African Americans for building fortifications and carrying out menial tasks, and the Confederate government did not formally allow African Americans (free or slave) to join the army until a last minute desperate measure passed the Confederate Congress in March 1865, only weeks before the end of the war. Only around two hundred enslaved soldiers were organized into service, but they were not sent into combat.

By the time the last Confederate soldiers surrendered to Union forces in June 1865, nearly 100,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 160,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The 24th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized in September and October 1861 in Lauderdale County, Mississippi under the command of Col. William F. Dowd and served in the Western Theater under Walthall's and Brantly's Brigades in the Army of Tennessee. It was later commanded by Col. Robert P. McKelvaine. It was consolidated with the 27th, 29th, 30th, and 34th infantry regiments to form the 24th Regiment, Mississippi Consolidated Infantry on April 9, 1865. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 24; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 640-648; National Park Service-Battle Units)

Approximately 620,000 Americans died during the Civil War. For this reason, the war is often called America’s bloodiest conflict. However, two-thirds of Civil War deaths were caused by disease, not combat. The disparity is greater for non-fatal victims: 400,000 soldiers suffered wounds or injuries compared to 6,000,000 cases of illness. Since a combined 3,000,000 men fought in Union and Confederate armies, this means the average soldier fell ill to disease twice during his military service.

Numerous types of diseases afflicted soldiers and civilians during the Civil War and Reconstruction era. Some were ubiquitous, like the common cold and diarrhea, which rarely garnered much attention unless the symptoms worsened into a more severe condition. Pneumonia, typhoid, and malaria were among the most serious diseases in the mid-nineteenth century. Epidemics of yellow fever and small pox also ravaged some civilian communities and military units. Perhaps the most deadly to Civil War soldiers, though, was dysentery, which was diarrhea with blood in the stool. Nearly 60,000 people died from dysentery during the war, and Union officials recorded 1.5 million cases of diarrhea or dysentery between 1861 and 1865.

All Americans, regardless of economic status or race, suffered pain and loss due to illness during the era. The President of the United States Abraham Lincoln and President of the Confederate States Jefferson Davis—the two most powerful individuals in North America, with access to the best resources—each lost a child to disease during the Civil War. The problem worsened with the sudden shifting of human populations during and after the war, as outbreaks of diseases spread rapidly. While many soldiers from highly populated areas had developed immunity to childhood diseases such as chicken pox, diphtheria, mumps, measles citizen soldiers from rural areas proved more susceptible to severe reactions when exposed to those diseases. Physicians improved medical care during the Civil War, as many recognized the value of sunlight and fresh airflow. However, they could only provide soldiers such healthy conditions behind the lines, at hospitals or rest areas. In many camps, or in the field during campaigns, soldiers were exposed to poor weather, extreme temperatures, and unsanitary conditions. Those who suffered the worse were in prisoner of war camps, in both north and south, where thousands of soldiers died from dysentery or other diseases. Civil War doctors did not fully understand the spread of diseases, including contaminated water (in the case of typhoid and dysentery) or mosquitos (for malaria and yellow fever). As such, camps, forts, and prisons rarely were constructed with the soldiers’ health in mind, and Civil War medicine most often involved responding to disease rather than preventing it.

Another source of illness among soldiers, and civilians in war-torn areas, was dietary deficiencies. Despite efforts by subsistence and commissary personnel in Union and Confederate armies, feeding thousands of troops daily proved a monumental task. Food preservation techniques still relied heavily upon drying and salting, and fresh vegetables and fruits were limited and dependent upon seasons. As a result, most Civil War soldiers likely suffered from a Vitamin C deficiency, the most severe cases resulting in scurvy which caused the loss of teeth and bleeding. Heavy reliance upon corn-based foods, especially within southern military units or Union prisoners held in southern prisoner of war camps, led to high instances of pellagra, a condition caused by the lack of niacin (or vitamin B3). Present in most foods, but not corn, victims suffered from diarrhea, skin sores, and dementia.

Often ignored, Americans also suffered from sexually transmitted diseases during the Civil War and afterwards. Although rarely fatal, more than 100,000 soldiers were diagnosed with gonorrhea and nearly 80,000 became infected with syphilis. Unsurprisingly, most of these cases occurred when soldiers were near populated areas, especially during training or time in camp, where they had more opportunities to interact with women. Venereal disease rates were higher at the start and at the end of the Civil War. That trend may reflect the fact that rates went down for armies on campaign in the field. The overall rate of venereal disease in the Union Army fluctuated from about 82 to 87 cases for every 1,000 soldiers, Some Union military units reported extremely high rates of venereal disease, particularly in the west. For instance, military physicians in the Department of the Pacific recorded 461 cases out of 1,000 men in 1862.

The Civil War also led to disease outbreaks among civilians. Like country-born soldiers introduced to new diseases in military camps, fugitive or liberated slaves who congregated in refugee camps behind Union lines became exposed to new diseases. Cities besieged by armies, such as Vicksburg, Atlanta, and Richmond, faced problems with sanitation and food supplies, compromising the health and immune systems of local residents, leaving them more susceptible to illness.

Finally, while most people survived bouts of illness during the Civil War, countless carried pathogens back to their home communities, or simply carried long-term effects from diseases within their bodies. Respiratory infections, blood borne diseases, and other afflictions obtained during the war decreased the quality of life of many Americans, or led to other health complications and early death. (American Battlefield Trust, Frank R. Freemon, Gangrene and Glory: Medical Care during the American Civil War, 205–213; George Worthington Adams, Doctors in Blue, 3–5; Thomas P. Lowry, The Story the Soldiers Wouldn't Tell, 104–108)

div.p: Capt. Coopwood & his Company are still with the Regiment & we get on very smoothely. We are splendidly armed with Enfield Rifles—Dowd

His Excellency
Honl. Jno. J Pettus

I regret that my constant engagements have prevented an earlier redemp-tion of my promise to write you something in reference to the 24th Miss Regiment in the organization of which you rendered me such faithful & efficient assistance.

The journey, from Marion Station Miss to Savannah Ga. in open box cars in bitter terribly cold weather occuring soon after a recovery from the measels. laid up in the Hospital 200 men with cold and pneumonia. Before their recovery and before quite all the regiment had arrived, an attack was threatened on this place: which is regarded by our military men as a strategic point of the last importance, and we were ordered hither, coming part of the way by sea. We arrived safely this latter part of December. The utmost
div.note: NOTE: Thomas Benton Coopwood (1794-1862) was Captain of Company L of the 24th Mississippi Regiment. He equipped Co. L with his own funds. He was killed at Perryville, Kentucky on October 8, 1862; he was 68 years old. Fernandina, Fla (currently a suburb of Jacksonville) was the site of Fort Clinch, a Federal coastal defense fort. It was abandoned by the Confederates in March 1862. The 24th was sent there from Savannah by Gen Lee. The fort was ultimately abandoned when Federal troops attacked. William Francis Dowd (1820-1872) was a lawyer who organized the 24th Mississippi; he led the unit until illness forced him to resign in 1864.

div.p: care has been taken of our sick, as is evidenced by the fact that only 1 out of 11 companies & an aggregate of over 950 hundred have died, since the men were mustered into service which has now been over from four to five months. I refuse furloughs under any & all circumstances, but instruct the surgeons, that whenever a mans vital parts, become so much & so deeply diseased as to render him unfit for duty for a long time and his recovery improbable in camp, to discharge ^to certify the fact & I have him discharged^ in time to save his life if possible. We are now getting through the mumps, the last camp disease, and the health of the regiment is becoming very good. The Mississippians are placed on the main land with some other forces, & battens, under my command as a separate Post. Further particulars it would be improper to give. My Pickets extend up & down the coast some twenty miles, and we are now daily expecting an attack, especially since the occupation by the enemy of Cedar Key the Gulf terminus of the Peninsula Rail Road. Fernandina has a splendid Harbor, on the Atlantic Coast & is the other terminus of the same road. It is 60 hours from New York There is no doubt now from information in our possession, that the enemy intend to take Fernandina, take possession of the whole Peninsula Rail Road, before their attack on New Orleans & Mobile, as a key to those important places. This would enable them to send reinforcements from& provisions, munitions of war &c. &c. in five days from New York to Ship Island & would avoid all the danger of doubling the Southern Capes of Florida, and above all the dangers & diseases of a sea voyage which is too long for a large expedition or for the health of man or beast. A large expedition sailed on the 4th inst doubtless intended for this important service. The fighting standard of Mississippi was elevated very high at Manassas—placed a little higher at Leesburg placed a little higher if possible at Somerset. We will try hard to keep it there and push

it a little higher. How we shall succeed &c can only be known when the day of trial comes, and I forbear to make a prediction—We have drilled very close and hard, and are becoming respectable. Few Regiments have got along more harmoniously. Not a single commissioned or non commissioned officer has been convicted of any offence by a Court Martial, although the laws of war are strictly and rigidly enforced. All seem to feel that the honour of our glorious State is in our keeping in a strange land, & are determined to do all in their power to make this Regiment efficient and worthy of the honoured [?] it bears.

I am Govr
Very Resp
Your friend & obt Servt,
I shall be glad to hear from you I will send you a report of the first fight if I live through it. D.
